name.en: Selected Readings on East Asian Art History

notice.ch: 英語授課。分發條件之外的同學（包括大三、大四同學）欲選修，須先與教師洽談領取密碼卡

remark.ch: 英語授課。分發條件之外的同學（包括大三、大四同學）欲選修，須先與教師洽談領取密碼卡

goal.ch:
本課程主要透過引導學生閱讀相關中、英論文的方式，讓學生了解中國繪畫（以清代以前的作品為主）的收藏和研究如何在近代以來以美國為首的西方世界中被建構和進行。
為了達成此一目標，課程主要分成兩大部份。首先，讓學生認識十九世紀末以來美國大規模收藏包括中國繪畫在內的東亞文物的時代背景。接著，進一步聚焦在中國繪畫，讓學生熟悉美國主要收藏機構的歷史和藏品，並對二十世紀初以來英語圈研究中國繪畫的歷程與轉變有所掌握。
 除此之外，本課程也希望藉著事先閱讀和課堂討論，以及口頭、書面報告的規劃，讓學生得以熟稔，並進而運用英語學界在東亞藝術史（特別是中國繪畫史）方面的學術用語。
goal.en:
This course aims to help students understand how the collection and study of Chinese paintings (mainly works created before the Qing Dynasty) have evolved in the U.S.-led modern Western world. This goal is achieved through guided reading of relevant academic papers in both English and Chinese. 
This course is divided into two parts. First, Students will explore the historical background of the American trend, beginning in the late 19th Century, toward the large-scale collection of East Asia cultural relics including Chinese paintings. Second, Students will examine how the major American museums acquired their Chinese painting collections and gain insight into the development of Chinese painting research in the English-speaking world since the early 20th century.  
Additionally, this course seeks to familiarize students with English academic terminology related to East Asian art history through pre-class reading, class discussion, and both oral and written reports.

outline.ch:
第一週 2/20 課程簡介
第二週 2/27 美國對東亞文物的興趣與收藏（一）從中國風到日本主義
第三週 3/06 美國對東亞文物的興趣與收藏（二）費諾羅沙、佛利爾、福開森所起的作用
第四週 3/13 美國對東亞文物的興趣與收藏（三）日、中文物商的中介與華爾納的敦煌探險
第五週 3/20 美國對東亞文物的興趣與收藏（四）龍門石窟的掠奪與倫敦中國藝術國際展覽會的影響
第六週 3/27 美國對東亞文物的興趣與收藏（五）日本文物的再度外流與台灣故宮的赴美首展
第七週 4/03 兒童節補假，停課一次
第八週 4/10 期末報告之初步規劃討論
第九週 4/17 美國的中國繪畫收藏（一）波士頓美術館和佛利爾美術館
第十週 4/24 美國的中國繪畫收藏（二）納爾遜‧阿特金斯藝術博物館、西雅圖亞洲藝術博物館、克利夫蘭美術館
第十一週 5/01 美國的中國繪畫收藏（三）大都會美術館、普林斯頓大學美術館
第十二週 5/08 英語圈的中國繪畫研究（一）1900年代至1950年代
第十三週 5/15 英語圈的中國繪畫研究（二）1960年代至1980年代
第十四週 5/22 英語圈的中國繪畫研究（二）1990年代以後
第十五週 5/29 參觀中央研究院歷史文物陳列館（視展覽情況調整參觀週次）
第十六週 6/05 參觀國立故宮博物院北部院區（視展覽情況調整參觀週次）
第十七週 6/12 期末口頭報告
第十八週 6/19 期末口頭報告
（實際授課內容待開學與同學討論之後，或有調整。）
outline.en:
1st Week 2/20  Course Introduction
2nd Week 2/27  The American Pursuit of East Asian Cultural Relics (1) From Chinoiserie to Japonisme
3rd Week 3/06  The American Pursuit of East Asian Cultural Relics (2) The Role of Fenollosa, Freer, and Ferguson
4th Week 3/13  The American Pursuit of East Asian Cultural Relics (3) Agency of Japanese and Chinese Art Dealers and Warner’s expedition to Dunhuang
5th Week 3/20  The American Pursuit of East Asian Cultural Relics (4) The Plundering of Longmen Grottoes and the Influence of the International Exhibition of Chinese Art in London
6th Week 3/27  The American Pursuit of East Asian Cultural Relics (5) The Renewed Flow of Japanese Cultural Relics Abroad and the First U.S. Exhibition of the National Palace Museum
7th Week 4/03  The class will be temporarily suspended in observance of Children’s Day.
8th Week 4/10  Discussion and Feedback on Preliminary Plans for Final Presentations
9th Week 4/17  Chinese Painting Collections in America (1) Boston Museum of Fine Art and Freer Gallery
10th Week 4/24  Chinese Painting Collections in America (2) Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art, Seattle Asian Art Museum, and Cleveland Art Museum
11th Week 5/01  Chinese Painting Collections in America (3) Metropolitan Museum of Art and Princeton Art Museum
12th Week 5/08  Studies on Chinese Painting in the English-speaking World (1) From the 1900s to the 1950s
13th Week 5/15  Studies on Chinese Painting in the English-speaking World (1) From the 1960s to the 1980s
14th Week 5/22  Studies on Chinese Painting in the English-speaking World (2) After the 1990s
15th Week 5/29  Field Trip to the Museum of Institute of History and Philology (The visiting schedule will be adjusted based on the exhibition‘s conditions.)
16th Week 6/05  Field Trip to the National Palace Museum Northern Branch (The visiting schedule will be adjusted based on the exhibition‘s conditions.)
17th Week 6/12  Final Presentation
18th Week 6/19  Final Presentation
(The actual course content may be adjusted after discussions with students at the beginning of the semester.)

textbook.ch:
1st Week 2/20
Course Introduction 
2nd Week 2/27
☆Warren Cohen, East Asian Art and American Culture: A Study in International Relations, New York: Columbia University Press, 1992, ch.1.
(孔華潤 〔Warren Cohen〕著,段勇譯，《東亞藝術與美國文化：厘析東亞藝術在美國兩百年的鑒藏之路》，上海：上海書畫出版社，2014年。)
‧Chelsea Foxwell, “Japan as Museum? Encapsulating Change and Loss in Late-Nineteenth-Century Japan,” Getty Research Journal, No. 1 (2009), pp. 39-52. 
‧田春，〈中國風“chinoiserie”的歷史與衍義〉，《美術》，2023年3期，頁15-25。
3rd Week 3/6
☆Warren Cohen, East Asian Art and American Culture: A Study in International Relations, ch.2.
・Steven Conn, “Where Is the East?: Asian Objects in American Museums, from Nathan Dunn to Charles Freer,” Winterthur Portfolio, Vol. 35, No. 2/3 (Summer-Autumn, 2000), pp. 157-173.
‧司開國，〈《福氏所藏物品清冊》與福開森中國藝術品收藏之路〉，《美術研究》，2020年2期，頁68-74。
4th Week 3/13
☆Warren Cohen, East Asian Art and American Culture: A Study in International Relations, ch.3.
‧Constance J. S. Chen, “Merchants of Asianness: Japanese Art Dealers in the United States in the Early Twentieth Century,” Journal of American Studies, Vol. 44, No. 1 (February 2010), pp. 19-46.
‧鄒清泉，〈盧芹齋—盧吳公司與二十世紀中國文物外流的幾個問題〉，《美術學報》，2024年2期，頁16-23。
5th Week 3/20
☆Warren Cohen, East Asian Art and American Culture: A Study in International Relations, ch.4.
‧Jason Steuber, “The Exhibition of Chinese Art at Burlington House, London, 1935-36,” The Burlington Magazine, Vol. 148, No. 1241 (Aug., 2006), pp. 528-536.
‧ Karl E. Meyer and Shareen Blair Brysac, The China Collectors: America‘s Century-long Hunt for Asian Art Treasures, New York: Palgrave Macmillan Trade, 2015, ch.5.
（卡爾‧梅耶〔Karl E. Meyer〕、謝林‧布萊爾‧布里薩克〔Shareen Blair Brysac〕著，張建新譯，《誰在收藏中國：美國獵獲亞洲藝術珍寶百年記》，北京：中信出版社，2016，第五章。）
6th Week 3/27
☆Warren Cohen, East Asian Art and American Culture: A Study in International Relations, ch.5.

‧Noelle Giuffrida, Separating Sheep from Goats: Sherman E. Lee and Chinese Art Collecting in Postwar America, Oakland, California: University of California Press, 2018, ch.5.

The class will be temporarily suspended in observance of Children’s Day.

8th Week 4/10
Discussion and Feedback on Preliminary Plans for Final Presentations

‧張建宇，〈收藏東方：美國波士頓美術博物館亞洲藏品的建立〉，《美術觀察》，2020年7期，頁87-90。
‧久世夏奈子著，范麗雅譯，〈岡倉覺三與波士頓美術館〉，《世界美術》，2022年2期，頁51-64。
10th Week 4/24
☆Josh Yiu, A Fuller View of China: Chinese Art in the Seattle Art Museum, Seattle: Seattle Art Museum, 2014, Ch.2.
‧瞿煉、朱俊，〈翰墨薈萃克利夫蘭：李雪曼和克利夫蘭藝術博物館的中國繪畫收藏〉，《紫禁城》，2014年4期，頁138-147。
‧高居翰，〈早期中國畫在美國博物館—一個「局內人」之見〉，收入上海博物館編，《翰墨薈萃：細讀美國藏中國五代宋元書畫珍品》，北京：北京大學出版社，2012年，頁50-83。
11th Week 5/1

‧Maxwell K. Hearn, “Wen C. Fong and Asian Art at the Metropolitan Museum,” Orientations, Vol.37 (Mar. 2006), pp.
‧紹彥，〈美國博物館藏中國古畫概述〉，收入上海博物館編，《翰墨薈萃：細讀美國藏中國五代宋元書畫珍品》，北京：北京大學出版社，2012年，頁84-99。 
12th Week 5/8

13th Week 5/15

（謝伯軻，〈西方中國繪畫史研究專論〉，收入洪再新編《海外中國畫研究文選》，上海：上海人民出版社，1992。）
・姜一涵，〈一九六○以來美國對中國藝術史研究之概況及趨勢〉，《美術學報》，10期，1976年1月，頁1545-1556。
・陳葆真，〈中國繪畫研究的過去與現在〉，《漢學研究通訊》，28卷3期，2009年8月，頁1-16。
14th Week 5/22
☆Jonathan Hay, “Toward a Disjunctive Diachronics of Chinese Art History,” RES: Anthropology and Aesthetics, No.40(Autumn 2001), pp.101-111.
・Wen Fong, “Why Chinese Painting Is History,” The Art Bulletin, Vol.85, No.2(Jun. 2003), pp.258-280.
・李惠子，〈由西向東—近年來西方研究中國美術史方法述評〉，《美術評論與理論》，2017年3期，頁67-72。
15th Week 5/29
☆張谷銘，〈Philology與史語所：陳寅恪、傅斯年與中國的「東方學」〉，《中央研究院歷史語言研究所集刊》，87卷2期（2016年6月），頁375-460。
16th Week 6/5
☆石守謙，〈清室收藏的現代轉化—兼論其與中國美術史研究發展之關係〉，《故宮學術季刊》，23卷1期（2005年秋），頁1-33。
17th Week 6/12
Final Oral Presentation
（期末口頭報告）
18th Week 6/19
Final Oral Presentation
（期末口頭報告）

gradMethod.ch:
1.課堂出席與討論參與20％：學生須於上課前至少閱讀前有☆的指定讀物，並於課堂中參與討論。
2.課堂口頭報告20％：自第三週起，學生須輪流就前有☆的論文進行介紹和評論。
3.期末口頭報告20％和書面報告（含期中繳交之初步規劃）40％：
①學生須選定一件美國博物館或美術館收藏的清代以前中國繪畫作為期末報告的對象作品，並於4/10繳交該作品的圖檔和相關前人研究的清單。
②學生須於6/12或6/19對所選定的作品進行口頭報告，內容須包括（1）作品流傳史（2）作品視覺分析（3）作品研究回顧（4）尚待開拓的研究課題。
③學生須根據口頭報告的內容和教師、同儕的回饋寫成書面報告，並於期末口頭發表後兩週內繳交。
gradMethod.en:
1.Class Attendance and Participation in Discussions 20％: Students must at least complete assigned readings marked with a ☆ before class and engage in discussions during the session. 
2.Class Presentation 20％：Starting from the 3rd week, students will take turns introducing the papers marked with a ☆ and providing a commentary on their arguments.
3.Final Presentation 20％ and Final Report (including the preliminary plan submitted mid-semester) 40％：
①Students are required to choose a Chinese painting created before the Qing Dynasty from an American collection as the subject of their final report. They must submit an image file of the painting and a list of relevant previous research on April 10th. 
②Students must deliver a presentation on the selected painting, scheduled for June 12th or 19th. The presentation should cover the following aspects of the selected painting: (1) its provenance (2) visual analysis (3) a review of relevant research, and (4) potential research topics for further exploration. 
③Within two weeks after the final presentation, students must submit a written report, based on their final presentation and feedback from the teacher and peers.
